pros: - flexible schedule - supportive staff
cons: this job really fit my needs as needed. no cons.

job_title: Department Business Administrator in Chicago, IL
pros: Safe and friendly environment. Good co-workers, small and attractive main campus. Located in a nice part of the northwest side of Chicago. Close to public transportation. Two well-recognized satellite locations, Carruthers Center in Bronzeville and El Centro in Avondale. Good academic programs and faculty. Graduates from Northeastern's Goodwin College of Education are sought after for their thorough, ready-to-teach preparation. Very good counselor education, social work, business, and science programs. Very good visual and performing arts programs, and performing spaces. Exceptional ethnic and cultural diversity; a very good representation of what the U.S. society actually looks like. Diverse faculty and administration which is a good reflection of the student body.
cons: On its face, NEIU appears to be a model for what U.S. society strives to be. You don't need to scratch the surface too hard to see the cockeyed politics and how the functional aspects of diversity really play out. Also, this university is finally emerging from technology of the 20th century...yes, you read that correctly. Until recently, paper forms, typewriters, and fax machines were regularly seen around the campus. While located in a lovely neighborhood, the main campus is in a food desert. The Board of Trustees is also a good demonstration of how important it is to vet appointees. The last crop of "trustees" caused so much chaos and damage to the institution, it is going to be a long road back.

pros: Good benefits, good work environment
cons: Pay could be much better

job_title: Student Peer Mentor in Chicago, IL
pros: It was great to work with students, it was the most rewarding part.
cons: It was hard to fully support students with financial aid issues when the students did not feel helped or welcomed at the financial aid office.

pros: Co-workers would be flexible to work with.
cons: Can't work for more than 10 hours

pros: Their vision is great and serves the Latino population.
cons: Lack of employees and money makes it difficult to work.

pros: NEIU still has some amazing and talented people who work tirelessly for student success. The main campus is large with some very open natural spaces that are rare in the city.
cons: Financial pressures from falling enrollments are prompting failures in leadership beginning at the highest levels, including the Board of Trustees. Cascading negative effects from these failures serve to maintain a constant state of crisis. This situation has motivated many of the key staff with marketable skills to find opportunities elsewhere.

pros: Great camaraderie among staff members, decent salaries
cons: Leadership makes poor misinformed decisions; does not listen to front line workers; (Dr. Huhs is Not the CEO/president and has not been for years)

review_title: Work Study for UTS - Media Services
pros: Ideal student job on campus Learned a lot about AV systems Worked with great co-workers Meet a lot of instructors and administration on campus
cons: Limited to 20 hours per week (per work study and student aid programs)

job_title: Admissions and Records Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Overall nice place to work.
cons: Management is not much productive.

review_title: it is cool place for work
pros: it is good environment for working

pros: Family oriented and flexible work schedule.
cons: Unorganized departments. Everyone works in silos and the administration is not really respected. Staff and faculty burnt out and morale is low.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Chicago, IL
pros:
Students who transfer in are well prepared and ready to tackle their ambitions. Many students are career changers who are hardworking and dedicated to making lives in Chicago better.

Colleagues are supportive and everyone is dedicated to helping students succeed. 

Many opportunities for collaborating across different units.
cons:
Challenging climate

Understaffed means we are overworked

Freshmen often struggle to find their motivation and to create the structure and discipline to be successful college students, and we don't always have sufficient resources to support them.

pros: The students are great, as are many colleagues.
cons: Chronically underfunded, incompetent and bloated administration, in the midst of a bad enrollment crisis. It's like a sinking ship. Everyone who can is leaving. I've been here 10 years, I have tenure, and I don't know if I'll have a job in 2 or 3 years.

pros: Great benefits, tuition waiver for civil service positions & work-life balance.
cons: Outdated systems in place, no remote work policy available, uncertainty around university future. No growth opportunities in your role.

pros: great employers, community driven, great team work.
cons: nothing so far since i haven't been there for long.

pros: Northeastern Illinois University has great benefits and work-life balance.

review_title: Friendly environment at the McNair Program
pros:
The program helps low-income students to succeed in graduate college.
The program encourages all employees to keep studying and growing professionally. It even helps with tuition at NEIU.
The program teaches you to be proficient and multi-tasking in different administrative fields.
The program's people create a friendly environment to work and create pathways to succeed beyond the program.
cons: The stipends and salaries are low compared to other universities

pros: Caring staff, respectful. It felt like a family there.

pros: Enjoyed the work environment and coworkers.

pros: None that can come to mind

pros: Good Place to work at
cons: No room for growth here

pros: Academic job in great location, urban Chicago.  Some departments are excellent, in terms of the faculty both in professional and personal co-worker terms.  A sometimes rewarding diversity of students.  Faculty can take classes for free, for credit.
cons: Weak union, low pay, pressure to keep academic standards low, very bad academic reputation can hurt career potential after a stint here, peculiar portfolio tenure retention process involves even more subjectivity and uncertainty than usual.  Very little university level support for research and publication and yet the tenure process involves relatively high expectations at the same time.

pros: Ez to commute, great public transportation,  free parking, can go to school right there
cons: I was fired on the last hour of my last day unexpectedly.  Reason given was my typing , & the Director told me I did not fit in.  He said  I was a good employee, & I should resign, & find another job at NEIU.  He  would give me an outstanding recommendation.  Never did, what a liar.  Had his friend replace me.  What was really disturbing & they never could explain was loaning me out to other library departments.  He later lied to the University President when I protested what happened.  Claimed I resigned under no pressure.  There is an illegal gambling pool that I was told to join, goes by check numbers every 2 weeks & costs 10 bucks.   Plus, being a new employee, was given a mop & a broom & told to clean the employee lounge.  Plus, when they hit u up for charitable contributions to buy tickets, better buy one to keep your job.

job_title: Special Events Facilitator in Chicago, IL
pros: I loved the diverse environment and university culture. NEIU was of the few places I felt comfortable to just be myself. Also had one of the best managers who I felt like actually supported me in every way and was approachable. I had the opportunity to grow and become involved in other university councils or groups.
cons:
Very strong union presence, which led to my unemployment.  The state is going through a terrible budget crisis right now, and I was last one in, first one out when it came to eliminating people.  I wish I could have worked there longer, but my manager and director really supported me and gave me great reviews when I had to find employment elsewhere. 
Also, for Chicago, the pay was very low to comparable positions, but the work/life balance made up for that, in my opinion.

review_title: Great place to gain great experience.
pros: Great, safe environment at a higher education setting.  Co-workers and students are very diverse and great people.  Can get great experience and opportunities; equal opportunities given on experience or education. Schedules are flexible.  Great opportunities for personal growth including tuition benefits.  Great benefits including vacation, sick & personal time, as well as health and retirement.
cons: NEIU is a public state university, thus there is lower pay for employees who have similar positions in private companies and organizations.  Staff can be neglected in comparison to faculty and administrators.

review_title: Love the students; not the drama
pros: The students were/are wonderful.  I enjoyed working with them, and was sad to leave them.  They are some of the most driven students I have met.
cons: The politics at any organization and institution is a given, but this institution in particular takes the cake for one of the worst.  The high turnover rate of newer employees is a testament to that. There are many employees working there that should no longer be employed at the institution based on things said and done, yet are given raises and promotions when others who are motivated and dedicated to the students are just pushed to the side.

review_title: The best supervises I worked with in the positions at Northeastern Illinois University.
job_title: Office Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: I had great supervise, who went the extra mile to assistant me I learn new skills for the position. I was accommodate,  fits into my schedule while I were studying. The people I work with were the best part of this company and encouraging.
cons: Their were professional leadership among the people I work with. I  enjoy work position it's were exciting to learn the job requirement and I enjoy working and studying with diversity.

pros: The students, hands down. Most were truly awesome. A lot of the faculty were great. Some of the staff was awesome.
cons: One of the biggest problems is that they do not value their employees and instead promote and keep around toxic employees, vs. those that work hard. The leadership is horrible. The union is strong, and therefore there are many many many people working there that should have been fired many years ago.

pros: Interacting with students taking classes in my major, helping people understand concepts I was passionate about, sharpen my editorial skills, time to do my own work when I had no students
cons: compensation, management in the learning center wasn't the best, tutors that "drew in" (unfair as some professors gave extra credit to see us while others did not) more students were favored

review_title: Good Students, nice faculty, lousy raises.
pros:
If you know how to work the system you can get ahead without being a total brown noser. 

Great union!
Great benefits, including free education.
Students are humble and awesome!
cons: Hard to get a raise. The university seems to always be broke, but we keep hiring VPs and directors. One, very small unit, has 5 directors. so unnecessary.

pros: Great, diverse student population and some very dedicated colleagues in the humanities and social sciences. Urban location.
cons: Relatively low pay, very little support for research, authoritarian administration, stressful campus politics (revolving around conflicts between administration and faculty), lack of state funding (the current crisis). Current problems have led to very low morale among faculty and staff.

review_title: If you're interested in working as a Student, Campus Rec is a great place to apply
pros: It is a tight-knit community. The supervisors really care about the professional and personal development of employees. It is a great place to start while studying. While in the job, you learn skills such as team building, and depending on how you progress, there is an opportunity for supervisor positions.
cons: You're limited to part-time hours. Max 20 hrs per week.

pros: Managers always appreciate your performance and always motivate. Tuition reimbursement for classes you take. The office work place is good. The co-workers and manager create positive energy. Human resources make sure you are well treated and the university president appreciates your work. The cafeteria is great and good food. The work assignments are lot and depend on seasonal patterns.
cons: Limited growth in hourly rate. Only salaried employees get paid vacations.

review_title: Is NEIU next after Chicago State ?
pros: This is a state school. That means that all disasters caused by management will have no repercussions on them.. This is good if one can get a job in upper management at NEIU.

job_title: Office Support Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The 6 -free course credit benefit.
cons: No promotions or raises.  It doesn't matter how much experience you have gained in a department to the point of knowing how to do everyone's job.  In order to be promoted if a position becomes available you still have to take a test.  If you fail the test and they hire someone new to the company you have to train them.

review_title: I love working there it a good company that I grew in.
pros: The faculty are a unique and diverse group of people. The university is onto big and beautiful things and is taking the right steps to get there.
cons: Certain staff get walk over, over worked and appreciated.This makes morale hard within the university and allows staff to allow themselves to perform their jobs mediocre at best.

pros: NEIU is very diverse. I have had some amazing mentors and my supervisors always encouraged professional development.

review_title: Pleasant work environment, low pay, behind the times.
pros: Great students and educational mission, five weeks vacation.  Benefits are adequate, but declining.
cons: Poor performance is tolerated, they often don't know what they're doing.  Some people act like they're doing you a favor when they actually do their job.  Planning is haphazard.

pros: the co workers were great and very friendly. The hours you could work were very flexible and the supervisors were really awesome people.
cons: the only cons i can think of are the lack of total work hours one received and the minimal pay for the job, but that was due to me being a student worker.

pros: Flexible hours, great access to resources, meaningful work and great benefits
cons: Low pay compared to similar jobs.  Dependent on state and federal budgets - e.g. difficult and uncertain budget situation in the state is negatively affecting both staff and students.

pros: There is a if gym which is Open to everybody who works there. Flexible hours were the best benefit since schedule was emery Monday for the following week
cons: There is no such things like health insurance. Employees need to hire their own insurance if they want to have one and there was no sick day

pros: The students are hard working and diverse, many have jobs and families, almost all are serious about their studies.  Faculty are mainly great, lots of camaraderie and strong focus on teaching.
